The BZ reaction is now a classics of oscillatory reactions. But there is a bunch of them already known specially in heterogeneous catalysis. To name a few which I have done myself: H2 oxidation with O2 on Ni and also on Co catalysts. CO oxidation on Pt. Partial oxidation of methane on Ni. Reduction of NO2 on Pt. And my favorite personal, dry reforming of methane on Ni or Co catalysts. These are nice examples just to name a few. The nice concentric and sometimes spiral patterns shown by NileRed are basically the result of diffusion-controlled mass transport coupled to the reactions which propagate as wavefronts

This is a very pretty reaction. Thanks for showing it in such detail.
Last semester (Physics Master lecture) I actually learned about the dynamics of such systems and how structures can form from reaction-diffusion equations and other processes. This reaction was one example and it can be shown (by a simplified model of the reaction) that the pattern can be described by the so called complex Ginzburg-Landau equation. It is also somehow possible to get spiral patterns instead of concentric rings but I don't know what parameters are needed for that.

Edit: In the run at around 13:30 you can actually see spiral patterns in some places if you look close.

I know it's been nearly 3 years now, but have you tried using a completely new dish or cleaning your original one really well ?
My guess is that the lack of bubbles in the first run was due to the surface of the dish being very smooth. From a materials course in university I learned that both bubble formation in liquids and crystal formation in solids can be accelerated by having more nucleation sites (impurities) in the volume and at the edges. That's why your carbonated drink will decarbonate much faster in a dirty glass than a clean one.
Also, the lack of bubbles in the first run somehow correlated with having fewer/sparser reaction waves. It really looked like they were also triggered by nucleation sites, but not sure if that should apply to chemical reactions...

Another trigger for nucleation could have been dust or small crystals having formed in your solution (I'm not a chemist, don't know if that applies).

The history behind this reaction is kinda sad, Belousov had his work rejected by a bunch of journals because they thought the oscillation was inconsistent with the laws of thermodynamics (it wasn't) and that he had simply made an error somewhere, and he was forced to publish in an obscure journal. Later, Zhabotinsky replicated his results which resparked interest in the subject, but even at that point many western journals still continued to publish refutations rather that just try to replicate the experiment because there were already convinced Belousov was wrong (he wasn't)

I think the blue flash you see at the end is actually a second larger wave propagating across the entire dish. The is why it disrupts the edges of the smaller waves, because it is changing the concentration of the bromine ions across the dish at a different speed than the local reactions that produce the edges. Where there is a sufficiently wide band of red, the "flash" does not erase the reaction nucleus. But you notice that after the flash, many blue spots are erased and the reaction has to start again in certain areas of the dish. I am not an expert, but it seems to me that because this is an oscillating reaction,  the blue flash can be seen as a wave with a different frequency propagating across the dish.

Now, I'm definitely not any kind of expert in chemistry - although, thanks to your videos I'm now somewhat of a vicarious hobbyist and I love it. However, the thing that I find pretty weird is that positive feedback loop reaction. How many other reactions have this particular property (i.e. that a reactant is, like, directly regenerated in the same form)?

Perhaps it's not as rare as I think - but for all the high school and college chemistry courses I've taken, I can't remember any reactions doing that. Usually, if anything is being regenerated - it's as an ion. As well, googling generally for the topic didn't return much. Maybe I'm just confused or lack the knowledge, but is that one of the particularly weird things about this reaction?

The blue flash looks like the wave propagates along the glass, which would be 2D diffusion. This would explain why it travels very fast, in addition, the solution along the glass is not the same as the solution in the bulk. The reaction would be limited by mass transfer between the glass layer and bulk and that could explain why the half life of the wave is so short compared to the waves traveling in the bulk solution.

I flippin love the Belousov-Zhabotinsky reaction. It is, hands down, my favorite reaction in all of chemistry. It can be simulated and look pretty good using reaction-diffusion algorithms and I've implemented them a few times just to make neat patterns. Some cellular automata systems also produce images that look like dead-on recreations. Reaction-diffusion is also related to a lot of models, including some worked on by the venerable Alan Turing, for how pigmentation gets established in animals during morphogenesis. I would really love it if there was anyone who could determine a way for reactions such as this (that produce patterns over time, displaying complex dynamics in color) to be done simply without the need for such rarely-used (and hard to get!) reagents.

You may potentially be able to decrease the amount of bubbles by adding an agent which decreases surface tension

Glass has tiny imperfections on its surface and I think those might be acting as nucleation sites for the bubbles to form. If you soak the glass with water for 24hrs beforehand it will give the water time to diffuse in and fill the nucleation sites. I think you would have to let the glass sit in water for an appreciable amount of time, as surface tension and viscous effects prevent the tiny imperfections from being immediately filled. This could help to reduce the amount of bubbles forming on the surface of the glass. Might be worth a shot :)
